words.origin: Late Middle English (as a verb): from French lamenter or Latin lamentari, from lamenta (plural) ‘weeping, wailing’.

noun.definition: A passionate expression of grief or sorrow.
noun.example: his mother's night-long laments for his father

transitive verb.example: he was lamenting the death of his infant daughter

transitive verb.definition: Say or do something to remove the doubts or fears of (someone)
transitive verb.example: he understood her feelings and tried to reassure her

words.origin: Early 19th century of dialect origin, perhaps from troll.

noun.definition: short for trolley car or trolley bus

noun.example: In later years, the tarries were electrified, and poles held the trolley wire.

noun.definition: A large metal basket or frame on wheels, used for transporting heavy or large items, such as supermarket purchases or luggage at an airport or railroad station.
